**Selective Readings in English and American Literature**

**Spring 2018**

**Instructor: Prof. Tsu-Chung Su (****蘇子中)**                 

**Office:** **英語系 823     Tel: 7734-1777**

E-mail: [tcsu@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:tcsu@ntnu.edu.tw)

### Course Objectives

This course sets out to introduce and examine selective works of different genres in English and American Literature. We will read a wide gamut of literary works that will enable us to look critically at such complex issues and themes as the components and practices of feminism, _carpe diem_, love-hate relationship, and sacrifice. Other than selected dramatic works such as Eve Ensler’s _Vagina Monologues_ and William Shakespeare’s _Romeo and Juliet_, we will also read poems that have a bearing on the theme of _carpe diem_ and Oscar Wilde’s short stories that have an obsessed focus on sacrifice. We will study all these texts intensely through close reading within class and practice viewing a text through the prism of different critical approaches or frameworks. This course is suitable for beginning students and should serve as preparation for further study in either dramatic literature, poetry, and novels. Lively discussion, debate, and differences of opinion will be crucial to our class meetings.

**Course Requirements and Evaluations**

1.  Thoughtful, active, and responsible participation and citizenship, including oral

discussion, preparation for class. Attendance is a very important part of the requirement—in excess of 3 absences is the ground for failure.

2.   In-class group oral reports. Please prepare your powerpoint according to the format below as a way to define the context and the issues of the reading.

1.  The Life and Work of the Author
2.  Plot Summary and the Structure of the Work
3.  Themes and Issues of the Work
4.  Character Analyses (Single out at least three most important speeches of each character)
5.  Style and Technical Features
6.  Critical Reception & Commentary

The oral presentation grading will give considerable weight to clarity of

organization and to the quality of the oral delivery. (25 %)

3.   There will be a mid-term quiz (25 %) and three in-class individual or group performance projects (25 %) and a final 3-page term paper (25 %).
